ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to approach literary and non literary translations, what it means to translate, the political implication of this creative practice as well as a new perspective on the diffusion of a text (just to name a few)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: One of the main strengths was certainly the range of materials covered and the choice of secondary readings, which allowed students to capture new aspects in authors and texts they may have already been familiar with and to approach new authors with even greater curiosity. Sometimes there were maybe too many primary texts assigned for one session, which made it impossible to cover everything, but it was still incredibly useful to have access to such a vast range of sources.
The professors would need to provide feedbacks faster.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. It is certainly one of the best courses that I have taken at Yale so far. It combines an excellent range of twentieth- and twenty-first-century Italian literature with a compelling theoretical framework on language and translation.
Yes, I would. I think anyone working in humanities should take a class like this one.
